title: Democratic rivals try to bring Elizabeth Warren back down to earth
text:
SAUL LOEB/AFP via Getty Images Democratic presidential candidate Elizabeth Warren was on the defensive at Tuesday’s debate.

If you had missed Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren’s ascent to front-runner status in the Democratic presidential polls, it was everywhere apparent at Tuesday night’s debate, where her rivals came after her with guns a-blazing.

In previous debates, Warren had dodged the question of whether middle-class taxes would go up in order to pay for Medicare-for-All and received minimal pushback.

More news: Here’s what the Democrats said about health care during the debate

Her standard response — “Costs will go down for hard-working middle-class families” — which isn’t an answer to the question posed, pretty much went unchallenged.

Tuesday night, her fellow Democrats would have none of it. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders said that most Americans will save money on health-care bills, but “taxes will go up.”

He should know because he “wrote the damn bill!”

Also read: Democrats spar over guaranteed jobs, universal basic income and $15 minimum wage

Others chimed in to criticize Warren’s evasiveness.

“At least Bernie’s being honest here and saying how he’s going to pay for this and that taxes are going to go up,” said Minnesota Sen. Amy Klobuchar. “We owe it to the American people to tell them where we’ll send the invoice.”

Former Vice President Joseph Biden confirmed that higher taxes would be required to cover Medicare-for-All’s estimated cost of $30 trillion over 10 years.

If Warren is convinced that Medicare-for-All is the best option for providing universal health care to all Americans, she should be up front about the source of the revenue needed to pay for it. That she bobs and weaves around the question is about as close as it gets to an admission that middle-class taxes will have to go up.

Democratic presidential candidates pretty much laid off Joe Biden and his son Hunter’s affiliation with Ukraine energy company Burisma at Tuesday’s debate. They seem willing to leave that potentially damaging affiliation — even if it’s only the optics when his father was vice president and in charge of addressing corruption in Ukraine — to President Donald Trump.

And Trump’s Twitter finger has a much broader reach than the TV debate audience.

Should Warren become the Democratic nominee, her fellow Democrats’ critiques of her free-for-all plans and questionable financing will provide serious fodder for Trump, which should prove more substantive that the derogatory name-calling he prefers in an effort to damage his challengers.

Klobuchar, who along with other candidates favors a public option for health care without kicking 149 million people off their private insurance, had other issues with Warren’s plans for health care and taxes.

“The difference between a plan and a pipedream is something that you can actually get done,” Klobuchar said.

Then there was the widespread opposition to Warren’s proposal for imposing a wealth tax of 2% on all assets above $50 million.

According to Warren, that revenue could be used to provide free universal child care and tuition-free college, cancel student loan debt for 95% of those who are carrying it, and fund programs for the poorest Americans, among other initiatives.

Aside from the fact that a wealth tax may not be constitutional — the introduction of the income tax in 1913 required a constitutional amendment — there are lots of reasons to doubt its effectiveness and ability to pay for all of Warren’s promises.

Entrepreneur Andrew Yang summed them up well, telling the audience that a wealth tax, which makes “a lot of sense in principle,” had been tried and rejected in an array of developed countries because it had “massive implementation problems and did not generate the [projected] revenue.”

Warren also equated opposition to a wealth tax to a desire to protect billionaires: a notion that did not sit well with Biden, Klobuchar, Yang and Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind.

Once again, Klobuchar hit back with a pointed critique.

“No one on this stage wants to protect billionaires. Not even the billionaire wants to protect billionaires,” she said, referring to hedge-fund-manager-turned-environmentalist Tom Steyer. “We just have different approaches. Your idea is not the only idea.”

Zing!

Warren may have garnered the most speaking time at the debate, but time doesn’t equate with electability. She was on the defensive much of the time, which supports the notion that her Democratic rivals view her as their No. 1 challenge and attacking her plans as their No. 1 priority.

And if her progressive policies are under attack from more moderate candidates seeking the Democratic nomination for president, one has to wonder how Warren will fare in a one-on-one match-up with Trump in 2020.
